text: was an old province of Japan in the area of Shizuoka Prefecture.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Tōtōmi" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 990. It is also known as . The province had borders with Mikawa, Suruga and Shinano Provinces. ==History== Tōtōmi was one of the original provinces of Japan established in the Nara period under the Taihō Code. In the Edo period, the Tōkaidō road was the main route between Kyoto and Edo. The road passed through Tōtōmi.Nussbaum, "Tōkaidō" at p. 973. In the Meiji period, the provinces of Japan were converted into prefectures. The maps of Japan and Izu Province were reformed in the 1870s.Nussbaum, "Provinces and prefectures" at p. 780. ==Shrines and Temples== Oguni jinja and Kotonomamahachimangū were the chief Shinto shrines (ichinomiya) of Tōtōmi."Nationwide List of Ichinomiya," p. 1 ; retrieved 2012-1-24. ==Related pages== * Provinces of Japan * Prefectures of Japan * List of regions of Japan * List of islands of Japan ==References== ==Other websites == * Murdoch's map of provinces, 1903 Category:Former provinces of Japan Category:Shizuoka Prefecture
